answers: I sold my house and had been in the market looking for a replacement house for over 6 months after I sold it. I found someone willing to give me a short term, 3 month lease, with a month to month after that, at an equitable rate, as renters were scarcer than buyers.By the time I found a house, there were bidding wars as surplus had declined (can be caused seasonally), and it was quite difficult to get my new house. However, appraisers help this to a degree because whatever the seller wants, is not necessarily what they get, even if you offer it. I offered $10k over asking just to get picked out of the large group bidding on the house. Once the appraisal came in at $10k below my offer, I was able to buy the house at what I expected. Of course I had to be prepared if it came in higher, but I did my homework and knew pretty much what the house was worth. The mortgage is the same as the lease I had, the house is only 10 years' old and has a 1 year warranty on large items that could go wrong. In the 3 months I've been in the house, I have gained nearly $8k in equity....and will have a tax writeoff of about $19,000 off an income off a salary of $72,000, giving me taxable income of $53,000... making by tax liability go down about $4600. If I am claiming 0 dependents I will get back about $5,000 this year versus breaking even.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Lost credit card replaced with new card and new numbers. Credit score affected?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, replacing a lost credit card can have an impact on your credit score. When you report a lost or stolen credit card to your issuer, they will typically issue you a new card with new numbers. This new card will have a new account number, which can affect your credit score in a few ways:

1. Credit utilization ratio: Your credit utilization ratio is the amount of credit you're using compared to the amount of credit available to you. When you get a new card with a new account number, your credit utilization ratio will increase, even if you haven't used the new card. This can negatively impact your credit score if you're already close to your credit limit.
2. Average account age: The age of your credit accounts is also considered in your credit score. When you get a new card, it will have a shorter age than your older accounts, which can lower your average account age. This can also negatively impact your credit score.
3. Credit mix: Your credit mix refers to the types of credit accounts you have (e.g., credit cards, loans, mortgages). When you get a new credit card, it may not have the same type of credit as your older accounts, which can affect your credit mix.

However, it's important to note that the impact of a lost credit card on your credit score is usually temporary and will resolve itself over
answers: The true answer is it depends because  it is up to the credit card issuer to follow the right path when issuing a replacement credit card. http://www.bankrate.com/finance/credit-cards/will-replacement-card-hurt-my-score.aspx Typically, issuers will transfer the account history to the new trade line, says Barry Paperno, the consumer operations manager at FICO, the creator of the FICO scoring formula. The new account should have the old open date, so you should retain your payment history, he says. The credit limit and balance should also stay the same. http://blog.credit.com/2014/02/lost-or-stolen-credit-card-hurt-your-credit-scores-76724/ How Issuers Report Replacement Cards We asked the major card issuers how they report replacement cards to credit reporting agencies: American Express: The new card has the same open date and “Member Since” year as the previous card. The balance on the old account number is transferred to the new account number. All payment history transfers over. Bank of America: All transactions and account history are transferred to the new account number when there is a card replacement or renewal. Capital One: The new account number with all the original account data (original open date, etc.) is reported along with a notification to the bureaus that the new account number is replacing the old.  The two tradelines can then be ‘merged’ into one, so that all the applicable payment history, balance, etc. is now under the new account number. Chase: The original tradeline does not change. The history on the account remains, just the account number field is updated with the new account number. There is no “new” tradeline in this scenario.

Yes, you can transfer money from a personal pension to a Self-Invested Personal Pension (SIPP) while leaving the original pension open. This is a common strategy for individuals who want to consolidate their retirement savings into a single pension pot.

When transferring money from a personal pension to a SIPP, the following rules apply:

1. The transfer must be made to a SIPP provider that is authorized by the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA).
2. The transfer must be done in writing, either by completing a transfer form provided by the SIPP provider or by writing to the provider directly.
3. The transfer must be made directly from the personal pension scheme to the SIPP provider. You cannot transfer money directly from your bank account to the SIPP provider.
4. The transfer must be made in accordance with the rules of the personal pension scheme and the SIPP provider. This may include paying any relevant transfer charges or taxes.
5. The transferred amount will be added to the SIPP and can be invested in a range of assets, such as stocks and shares, commercial property, and cash.

It's important to note that the original personal pension scheme must be left open after the transfer, as you cannot close it. This means that you will continue to pay any

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

How is your credit score related to credit utilization?[/INST]
pred:
Credit score and credit utilization are closely related factors that impact your creditworthiness. Your credit score is a three-digit number that lenders use to evaluate the risk of lending you money. It's based on information in your credit report, which includes your credit history, payment history, credit utilization, and other factors.

Credit utilization refers to the amount of credit you're using compared to the amount of credit available to you. It's calculated by dividing the amount of credit you're using (your balance) by the total credit limit on your accounts. For example, if you have a credit card with a $5,000 limit and a balance of $1,000, your credit utilization is 20%.

Your credit score is directly impacted by your credit utilization ratio. The lower your credit utilization, the better it is for your credit score. This is because it shows that you're using a small portion of your available credit, which indicates that you're responsible with credit and can manage your debt.

In general, it's best to keep your credit utilization below 30% for optimal credit scores. This means that if you have a $10,000 credit limit, you should aim to keep your balance below $3,000. Using too much of your available credit can negatively impact your credit score,

How is credit utiltization calculated?    Is it average utilization over the month, or total amount owed/credit_limit per month? It depends on how often your bank reports your balances to the reporting agencies. It can be daily, when your statement cycle closes, or some other interval. How does credit utilization affect your score?  Closest to zero without actually being zero is best. This translates to making some charges, even $1 so your statement shows a balance each statement that you pay off. This shows as active use. If you pay off your balance before the statement closes, then it can sometimes be reported as inactive/unused. Is too much a bad thing?  Yes. Is too little a bad thing? Depends. Being debt free has its advantages... but if your goal is to raise your credit score, then having a low utilization rate is a good metric. Less than 7% utilization seems to be the optimal level.  "Last year we started using a number, not as a recommendation, but as a fact that most of the people with really high FICO scores have credit utilization rates that are 7 percent or lower," Watts said. Read more: http://www.bankrate.com/finance/credit-cards/how-to-bump-up-your-credit-score.aspx Remember that on-time payment is the most important factor. Second is how much you owe. Third is length of credit history. Maintain these factors in good standing and you will improve your score: http://www.myfico.com/CreditEducation/WhatsInYourScore.aspx

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Do dividend quotes for U.S. stocks include witheld taxes?[/INST]
pred:
Thank you for asking! Dividend quotes for U.S. stocks typically do not include withheld taxes. When you buy a stock, the company will typically pay out dividends to its shareholders as a way of distributing profits. The dividend amount is usually expressed as a dollar amount per share, and this amount is what is called the "declared dividend."

However, the declared dividend amount does not include withheld taxes. Instead, the taxes are deducted from the dividend payment before it is distributed to shareholders. This means that the amount of money you actually receive in your bank account will be lower than the declared dividend amount, as the taxes will have been withheld.

For example, let's say you own 100 shares of Company XYZ and the company declares a dividend of $1 per share. If the withheld tax rate is 25%, the company will withhold $25 (25% of $100) in taxes from the dividend payment, leaving you with $75 in your bank account.

It's worth noting that the withheld taxes are typically held in an escrow account by the company until the end of the year, when they are remitted to the IRS. If you are a non-U.S. investor
answers: The dividend quoted on a site like the one you linked to on Yahoo shows what 1 investor owning 1 share received from the company. It is not adjusted at all for taxes. (Actually some dividend quotes are adjusted but not for taxes... see below.)  It is not adjusted because most dividends are taxed as ordinary income. This means different rates for different people, and so for simplicity's sake the quotes just show what an investor would be paid.  You're responsible for calculating and paying your own taxes.  From the IRS website: Ordinary Dividends Ordinary (taxable) dividends are the most common type of distribution from a corporation or a mutual fund. They are paid out of earnings and profits and are ordinary income to you. This means they are not capital gains. You can assume that any dividend you receive on common or preferred stock is an ordinary dividend unless the paying corporation or mutual fund tells you otherwise. Ordinary dividends will be shown in box 1a of the Form 1099-DIV you receive. Now my disclaimer... what you see on a normal stock quote for dividend in Yahoo or Google Finance is adjusted. (Like here for GE.) Many corporations actually pay out quarterly dividends. So the number shown for a dividend will be the most recent quarterly dividend [times] 4 quarters. To find out what you would receive as an actual payment, you would need to divide GE's current $0.76 dividend by 4 quarters... $0.19. So you would receive that amount for each share of stock you owned in GE.

Is it possible to block previously authorized ACH access?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, it is possible to block previously authorized ACH access. The National Automated Clearing House Association (NACHA) Rule 30 requires financial institutions to provide customers with the ability to request a stop or block of ACH transactions that have been previously authorized.

To block previously authorized ACH access, you can contact your financial institution and request that they stop the ACH transactions. They may require you to provide written confirmation of your request, such as a letter or email. Once the request is processed, the ACH transactions will be stopped, and any future transactions will not be processed.

It is important to note that stopping ACH transactions may not necessarily reverse any previous transactions that have already been processed. If you want to reverse ACH transactions, you may need to contact the originator of the transaction and request that they reverse the payment.

Additionally, it's important to be aware that blocking ACH transactions may not always be a permanent solution. Some ACH transactions, such as recurring payments or direct deposits, may automatically reactivate after a certain period of time. In these cases, you may need to contact your financial institution to revoke the authorization and prevent the transactions from occurring again.

Overall, while it is possible to block previously authorized ACH access, it's important to understand the potential consequences and limitations of doing so, and to seek the advice of

A low Canadian dollar (CAD) can have both positive and negative impacts on Canadian investors, depending on their individual circumstances and investment strategies.

Positive impacts:

1. Export-oriented businesses: A low CAD can make Canadian exports cheaper and more competitive in foreign markets, potentially leading to increased sales and revenue for businesses that rely on exports.
2. Tourism: A weak CAD can make traveling to Canada more attractive to foreign tourists, which can boost the tourism industry and generate additional revenue for related businesses.
3. Real estate: A low CAD can increase the attractiveness of Canadian real estate to foreign investors, particularly from the United States, as their dollars can buy more property in Canada.
4. Share prices: A low CAD can lead to higher share prices for Canadian companies that generate a significant portion of their revenue from outside of Canada, as their stocks become more attractive to foreign investors.

Negative impacts:

1. Import costs: A low CAD can increase the cost of imports, such as oil and gas, which can have a negative impact on Canadian consumers and businesses that rely on these imports.
2. Inflation: A low CAD can lead to higher inflation, as imports become more expensive, which can negatively impact consumer purchasing power and
answers: When you want to invest in an asset denominated by a foreign currency, your investment is going to have some currency risk to it. You need to worry not just about what happens to your own currency, but also the foreign currency. Lets say you want to invest $10000 in US Stocks as a Canadian. Today that will cost you $13252, since USDCAD just hit 1.3252. You now have two ways you can make money. One is if USDCAD goes up, two is if the stocks go up. The former may not be obvious, but remember, you are holding US denominated assets currently, with the intention of one day converting those assets back into CAD. Essentially, you are long USDCAD (long USD short CAD). Since you are short CAD, if CAD goes up it hurts you It may seem odd to think about this as a currency trade, but it opens up a possibility. If you want a foreign investment to be currency neutral, you just make the opposite currency trade, in addition to your original investment. So in this case, you would buy $10,000 in US stocks, and then short USDCAD (ie long CAD, short USD $10,000). This is kind of savvy and may not be something you would do. But its worth mentioning. And there are also some currency hedged ETFs out there that do this for you http://www.ishares.com/us/strategies/hedge-currency-impact However most are hedged relative to USD, and are meant to hedge the target countries currency, not your own.

What is the point of the stock market? What is it for, and why might someone want to trade or invest?[/INST]
pred:
The stock market is a platform that allows companies to raise capital by issuing stocks, and investors to buy and sell these shares. answers: A stop-loss order becomes a market order when a trade has occurred at or below the trigger price you set when creating the order. This means that you could possibly end up selling some or all of your position at a price lower than your trigger price. For relatively illiquid securities your order may be split into transactions with several buyers at different prices and you could see a significant drop in price between the first part of the order and the last few shares. To mitigate this, brokers also offer a stop-limit order, where you set not only a trigger price, but also a minimum price that you are will to accept for your shares. This reduces the risk of selling at rock bottom prices, especially if you are selling a very large position. However, in the case of a flash crash where other sellers are driving the price below your limit, that part of your order may never execute and you could end up being stuck with a whole lot of shares that are worth less than both your stop loss trigger and limit price. For securities that are liquid and not very volatile, either option is a pretty safe way to cut your losses. For securities that are illiquid and/or very volatile a stop-limit order will prevent you from cashing out at bottom dollar and giving away a bargain to lurkers hanging out at the bottom of the market, but you may end up stuck with shares you don't want for longer than originally planned. It's up to you to decide which kind of risk you prefer.

Can another tax loss be used to offset capital gains taxes? How does it work?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, another tax loss can be used to offset capital gains taxes in the United States. This is known as "tax loss harvesting."

Tax loss harvesting involves selling investments that have declined in value to realize a loss, which can then be used to offset gains from the sale of other investments. By doing so, you can reduce your tax liability on the capital gains from the sale of the investments.

Here's how it works:

1. Identify investments that have declined in value: Review your investment portfolio and identify investments that have lost value. These could be individual stocks, mutual funds, or exchange-traded funds (ETFs).
2. Determine the tax loss: Calculate the amount of the loss by subtracting the cost basis (the amount you paid for the investment) from the current market value.
3. Sell the investment: Sell the investment that has declined in value to realize the tax loss. You can sell the investment directly or use a tax-loss harvesting strategy, such as a "wash sale" rule, which allows you to sell the investment without triggering a wash sale and losing the tax loss.
4. Offset capital gains: Use the tax loss to offset capital gains from the sale of other investments. For example
answers: Capital losses do mirror capital gains within their holding periods. An asset or investment this is certainly held for a year into the day or less, and sold at a loss, will create a short-term capital loss. A sale of any asset held for over a year to your day, and sold at a loss, will create a loss that is long-term. When capital gains and losses are reported from the tax return, the taxpayer must first categorize all gains and losses between long and short term, and then aggregate the sum total amounts for every single regarding the four categories. Then the gains that are long-term losses are netted against each other, therefore the same is done for short-term gains and losses. Then your net gain that is long-term loss is netted against the net short-term gain or loss. This final net number is then reported on Form 1040. Example Frank has the following gains and losses from his stock trading for the year: Short-term gains - $6,000 Long-term gains - $4,000 Short-term losses - $2,000 Long-term losses - $5,000 Net short-term gain/loss - $4,000 ST gain ($6,000 ST gain - $2,000 ST loss) Net long-term gain/loss - $1,000 LT loss ($4,000 LT gain - $5,000 LT loss) Final net gain/loss - $3,000 short-term gain ($4,000 ST gain - $1,000 LT loss)   Again, Frank can only deduct $3,000 of final net short- or long-term losses against other types of income for that year and must carry forward any remaining balance.

Is a debt collector allowed to make a hard inquiry on your credit report?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, a debt collector is legally allowed to make a hard inquiry on your credit report when attempting to collect a debt. A hard inquiry is a type of credit inquiry that appears on your credit report and indicates that a lender or debt collector has accessed your credit report to evaluate your creditworthiness.

Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA), debt collectors are considered "creditors" and are allowed to make hard inquiries on your credit report for the purpose of collecting a debt. This means that if you have an outstanding debt with a collector, they may check your credit report to determine your creditworthiness and determine the best course of action for collecting the debt.

It's important to note that debt collectors are only allowed to make hard inquiries on your credit report for the purpose of collecting a debt, and they are not allowed to use your credit report for any other purpose. Additionally, debt collectors are required to follow the FCRA's guidelines when making hard inquiries on your credit report, which includes providing a clear and conspicuous disclosure to you that they are making the inquiry and informing you of your rights.

It's also worth noting that multiple hard inquiries on your credit report within a short period of time (usually 30 days)
answers: According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act: any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report [...] to a person which it has reason to believe [...] intends to use the information in connection with a credit transaction involving the consumer on whom the information is to be furnished and   involving the extension of credit to, or review or collection of an account of, the consumer See p12 (section 604). The usual interpretation of this that I've heard is that a debt collection agency that owns or has been assigned a debt can make hard pulls on your credit report without your consent. This link seems to support that (and references the same part of the act, among others): According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act, [...], any business can access your credit history without your permission provided the business has a valid "permissible purpose." The FCRA notes that one such permissible purpose is to review your credit information in connection with the collection of a debt. Thus, if you owe money to a debt collector, the debt collector has the legal right to pull and review your credit report. If they haven't been assigned the debt or own it outright, I believe you have a legal right to dispute it. Consult a lawyer if this is actually a situation you face.  Once use for this is if the debt collection agency has trouble locating you; since your credit report normally contains current and past addresses, this is one way to locate you.

Once the price reaches that level, the stop order is converted into a market order, which means that the trade is executed at the current market price. The main advantage of a stop order is that it allows investors to set a price level at which they want to buy or sell a security, without having to continuously monitor the market.

On the other hand, a stop limit order is an order to buy or sell a security when the price reaches a certain level, but only if it can be executed at a specified price or better. This means that if the price of the security reaches the stop price, but there are no buyers or sellers at that price, the stop limit order will not be executed. The main advantage of a stop limit order is that it allows investors to set a price level at which they want to buy or sell a security, while also controlling the maximum price at which the trade can be executed.

answers: An attempt at a simple answer for the normal investor: A normal investor buys stock then later sells that stock. (This is known as "going long", as opposed to "going short").  For the normal investor, a stop order (of either kind) is only used when selling. A stop-loss sell order (or stop sell) is used to sell your stock when it has fallen too much in price, and you don't want to suffer more losses.  If the stock is at $50, you could enter a stop sell at $40, which means if the stock ever falls to $40 or lower, your stock will be sold at whatever price is available (e.g. $35). A stop-loss limit sell order (or stop limit sell) is the same, except you are also saying "but don't sell for less than my limit price".  So you can enter a stop limit sell at $40 with a limit of $39, meaning that if the stock falls to $40, you will then have a limit order in effect to sell the stock at $39 or higher.  Thus your stock will never be sold at $35 or any value below $39, but of course, if the stock falls fast from $40 to $35, your limit sell at $39 will not be done and you will be left still owning the stock (worth at that moment $35, say).

The best thing to do is to shortlist a number of projects you like the sound of and then sit down and research each of them. As the price of oil futures contracts increases, the value of the ETFs also goes up, and vice versa.

Secondly, many ETFs that track the price of oil have a direct correlation with the price of oil per barrel. For example, the United States Oil Fund (USO) tracks the price of West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude oil, which is one of the most widely used benchmarks for oil prices. As the price of WTI crude oil increases, the value of the USO ETF also goes up.

Lastly, some ETFs may have a slightly different relationship with the price of oil per bar

A hedge is a financial instrument used to mitigate investment risk. It involves creating a position in a security or asset that is opposite to an existing position in another security or asset. This is done to reduce the potential losses from changes in the value of the original investment.

There are several types of hedges, including:

1. Forward Contracts: These are agreements to buy or sell an asset at a future date at a fixed price. For example, a farmer may enter into a forward contract to sell their crops at a certain price in the future to lock in a profit.
2. Futures Contracts: These are similar to forward contracts, but they are standardized and traded on an exchange. They allow investors to speculate on the future price of an asset or to hedge against potential losses.
3. Options: These give the holder the right, but not the obligation, to buy or sell an asset at a certain price at any time within a specified period. They can be used to hedge against potential losses or to speculate on the price of an asset.
4. Swaps: These involve exchanging cash flows based on different assets or liabilities. For example, a company may enter into a swap agreement to exchange interest payments based on a fixed rate for a floating rate.

Hedges can be used to manage a variety of
answers: In this type of strategy profit is made when the shares go down as your main position is the short trade of the common stock. The convertible instruments will tend to move in about the same direction as the underlying (what it can be converted to) but less violently as they are traded less (lower volatility and lower volume in the market on both sides), however, they are not being used to make a profit so much as to hedge against the stock going up. Since both the bonds and the preference shares are higher on the list to be repaid if the company declares bankruptcy and the bonds pay out a fixed amount of interest as well, both also help protect against problems that may occur with a long position in the common stock.  Essentially the plan with this strategy is to earn fixed income on the bonds whilst the stock price drops and then to sell both the bonds and buy the stock back on the market to cover the short position. If the prediction that the stock will fall is wrong then you are still earning fixed income on the debt and are able to convert it into stock at the higher price to cover the short sale eliminating, or reducing, the loss made on the short sale. The idea behind market-timing is that by actively timing the market, investors can avoid periods of high volatility or declining prices, and instead invest in areas that are perceived to be undervalued or have the potential for strong growth. prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

“Convertible -debt/note/bond/debentures” which of these are the same or different?[/INST]
pred:
Convertible debt, notes, bonds, and debentures are all financial instruments that allow investors to invest in a company with the potential for future equity ownership. While they share some similarities, there are also some key differences between these instruments.

Convertible debt is a type of debt security that can be converted into a predetermined number of shares of the company's common stock at a later date, typically at the investor's option. This means that the investor has the right to convert their debt into equity if they choose to do so, providing them with potential upside if the company's stock price increases.

Notes, on the other hand, are similar to debt securities but typically have a longer maturity date and may offer a higher interest rate than traditional bonds. Like convertible debt, notes can also be converted into equity at a later date.

Bonds are a type of fixed-income security that represents a loan made by an investor to a borrower (typically a corporation or government). Bonds typically have a set interest rate and maturity date, and the borrower is obligated to pay back the principal amount of the loan, along with the accrued interest, at the specified maturity date.

Debentures are a type of bond that is not secured by any specific assets
answers: They all basically mean the same thing - a type of debt than can be exchanged for (converted into) equity at some point. It's only the mechanics that can be different. A convertible bond is structured just like a regular bond - it (usually) pays periodic interest and has a face value that's due at maturity. The difference is that the bond holder has the option to exchange the debt for equity at some point during the life of the bond.  There can be restrictions on when that conversion is possible, and they typically define a quantity of equity (number of shares) that the bond can be converted into.  If the market price of the shares goes above a price that would make the shares more valuable than the bond, it's in the best interest of the bond holder to convert. A convertible note is typically used to describe a kind of startup financing that does not pay interest or have a face value that's redeemed, but instead is redeemed for equity as part of a later financing round.  Rather than specifying a specific number of shares, the bond holder receives equity at a certain discount to the rest of the market. So they both are debt instruments that can turn into equity investments, just through different mechanisms. A debenture is a fancy word for unsecured debt, and convertible debt could be used to described either structure above, so those terms could mean either type of structure.

Interest on an amount exceeding your credit card balance can occur when you carry a balance on your credit card from one billing cycle to the next. This is known as "carrying a balance" or "owing a balance on your credit card."

Here's how it works:

Let's say you have a credit card with a credit limit of $5,000. You use your card to make a purchase of $3,000, leaving a balance of $2,000 on your card. If your credit card has a variable interest rate of 18%, and you don't pay off the entire balance by the due date, you will be charged interest on the outstanding balance.

In this scenario, you will be charged interest on the entire $2,000 balance, even though you only exceeded your credit card balance by $1,000. This is because the interest rate is calculated on the entire outstanding balance, not just the amount that exceeds your credit card limit.

It's important to note that interest rates can vary depending on the credit card issuer and the terms of your credit card agreement. Some credit cards may have a fixed interest rate, while others may have a variable rate that can change over time. Additionally, some credit cards may offer promotional periods with 0% interest, which can provide relief from interest charges for a
answers: The best answer to this is: Read the fine print on your credit card agreement. What is common, at least in the US, is that you can make any charges you want during a time window.  When the date comes around that your statement balance is calculated, you will owe interest on any amount that is showing up as outstanding in your account.  Example...  To revise the example you gave, let's say Jan 1. your account balance was $0. Jan. 3rd you went out and spent $1,000.  Your account statement will be prepared every XX days... usually 30. So if your last statement was Dec. 27th, you can expect your next statement to be prepared ~Jan.24 or Jan. 27.  To be safe, (i.e. not accrue any interest charges) you will want to make sure that your balance shows $0 when your statement is next prepared.  So back to the example you gave--if your balance showed $1,000... and you paid it off, but then charged $2,000 to it... so that there was now a new set of $2,000 charges in your account, then the bank would begin charging you interest when your next statement was prepared.  Note that there are some cards that give you a certain number of days to pay off charges before accruing interest... it just goes back to my saying "the best answer is read the fine print on your card agreement."

answers: There is certainly an obligation in some cases of a company to distribute profit, either as dividend or a stock buy back. Companies in their growth phase often don't return any money and simply reinvest - but the long-term hope is to either return money in the form of dividends on profits, or the sale of the company.

answers: A huge amount of money in all financial markets is from institutional investors, such as mutual funds, government pension plans, sovereign wealth funds, etc.  For various reasons these funds do all of their trading at the end of the day.  They care primarily that their end-of-day balances are in line with their targets and are easy to audit and far less about "timing the market" for the best possible trades. So, if you're looking at a stock that is owned by many institutional investors -- such as a stock (like AAPL) that makes up a significant portion of an index that many funds track -- there will be a huge amount of activity at this time relative to stocks that are less popular among institutions. Electronic trading has done away with a lot of the straight-up thievery that floor traders and brokers used to get away with at the expense of the public, but it still exists. answers: The Creation/Redemption mechanism is how shares of an ETF are created or redeemed as needed and thus is where there can be differences in what the value of the holdings can be versus the trading price. If the ETF is thinly traded, then the difference could be big as more volume would be where the mechanism could kick in as generally there are blocks required so the mechanism usually created or redeemed in lots of 50,000 shares I believe. From the link where AP=Authorized Participant: With ETFs, APs do most of the buying and selling. When APs sense   demand for additional shares of an ETF—which manifests itself when the   ETF share price trades at a premium to its NAV—they go into the market   and create new shares. When the APs sense demand from investors   looking to redeem—which manifests itself when the ETF share price   trades at a discount—they process redemptions. So, suppose the NAV of the ETF is $20/share and the trading price is $30/share. The AP can buy the underlying securities for $20/share in a bulk order that equates to 50,000 shares of the ETF and exchange the underlying shares for new shares in the ETF. Then the AP can turn around and sell those new ETF shares for $30/share and pocket the gain. If you switch the prices around, the AP would then take the ETF shares and exchange them for the underlying securities in the same way and make a profit on the difference. SEC also notes this same process.

As mhoran_psprep said, some of it goes to pay interest to the depositors; some of it goes to pay the bank's expenses like employee salaries, cost of the building, etc; and some of it goes as profit to the owners or stockholders of the bank. If you're thinking, "Wow, I'm paying back a whole lot more than I borrowed", well, yes. But remember you're borrowing that money for 20 or 30 years. The bank isn't making very much money on the loan each year that you have it -- these days something like 4 or 5% in the U.S., I don't know what the going rates are in other countries.

UK Gilts are a type of government bond issued by the British government to raise funds from investors. The interest rates and repayments on UK Gilts work as follows:

Interest Rates:
Gilts are issued with a fixed interest rate, which is the percentage rate at which the government agrees to pay the investor the face value of the bond at maturity. The interest rate is set when the bond is issued and remains fixed for the life of the bond. For example, if you buy a 10-year GBP 1,000 Gilt with a fixed interest rate of 2%, you will receive GBP 1,000 in interest payments every year for 10 years, totaling GBP 100.

Repayment:
At maturity, the investor receives the face value of the bond, which is the amount originally invested. For example, if you buy a GBP 1,000 Gilt that matures in 10 years, you will receive GBP 1,000 at maturity, plus the interest payments you received over the 10-year period.

Yield:
The yield on a Gilt is the total return an investor can expect to earn from holding the bond, including the interest payments and any capital gains or losses. The yield is
answers: The name of the Gilt states the redemption date, but not the original issue date. A gilt with 8.75% yield and close to its redemption date may have been issued at a time when interest rates were indeed close to 8.75%. For example in the early 1990s, the UK inflation rate was about 8%. One reason for preferring high or low coupon gilts is the trade off between capital gains and income, and the different taxation rules for each. If you buy a gilt and hold it to its maturity date, you know in advance the exact price that it will be redeemed for (i.e. £100). You may prefer to take a high level of income now, knowing you will make a capital loss in future (which might offset some other predictable capital gain for tax purposes) or you may prefer not to take income that you don't need right now, and instead get a guaranteed capital gain in future (for example, when you plan to retire from work). Also, you can use the change in the market value of gilts as a gamble or a hedge against your expectation of interest rate changes in future, with the "government guaranteed" fallback position that if your predictions are wrong, you know exactly what return you will get if you hold the gilts to maturity. The same idea applies to other bond investments - but without the government guarantee, of course.

When does giving a gift “count” for tax year?[/INST]
pred:
In the United States, the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) considers gifts to be taxable income for the recipient when they are given in cash or in kind, and the value of the gift exceeds $15,000 in a single year. This threshold is known as the "annual gift tax exclusion."

Gifts that are below the annual gift tax exclusion do not have to be reported to the IRS, and they do not reduce the donor's lifetime gift tax exemption. However, if the value of the gifts given to one individual exceeds the annual exclusion, the recipient will be required to report the gift on their tax return.

It's important to note that the annual gift tax exclusion applies to gifts given to any individual, not just immediate family members. This means that you can give gifts to friends, nieces, nephews, and other loved ones without having to worry about gift tax implications.

If you are giving gifts to multiple individuals in a single year, it's important to keep track of the value of each gift to ensure that you don't exceed the annual exclusion. You can use a journal or spreadsheet to keep track of your gifts and their values throughout the year.

In addition to the annual gift tax exclusion, there are other gift tax rules to be aware of. For example
answers: Based on past case law, a check made payable to qualified charity and delivered (e.g., placed in the mail on 12/31 would count as delivered as it is out of the hands of the donor) would fall under the "constructive receipt doctrine". However, for non-charitable gifts (e.g., gifts to family members) it is the date the check is cashed (honored by the receiving bank).  This is important as the annual gift exclusion is just that "Annual".  Therefore, if I gift my child $14,000 by writing a check on 12/31/2014 but they deposit it on 1/3/2015 then I have used my annual gift exclusion for 2015 and not 2014.  This means I could not gift them anything further in 2015. BTW the annual gift amount is for ALL gifts cash and non-cash.  Most people don't seem to realize this.  If I give $14,000 of cash to my child and then also give them Christmas gifts with a value of $1,000 I have exceeded my annual gift exclusion to that child.  Usually there are ways around this issue as I can give $14,000 to each and every person I want and if married my spouse can do the same.  This allows us to give $14,000 from each of us to each child plus $14,000 from each of us to their spouse if married and $14,000 from each of us to each of their children if they have any.

answers: The price of the last trade... Is the price of the last trade. It indicates what one particular buyer and seller agreed upon. prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Investing in dividend-yielding stocks with money borrowed from margin account?[/INST]
pred:
Investing in dividend-yielding stocks with money borrowed from a margin account can be a viable strategy for generating passive income, but it's important to understand the risks involved.

When you invest in dividend-yielding stocks using borrowed money from a margin account, you are essentially leveraging your investment. This means that the potential gains from the investment are multiplied by the amount of money borrowed, but so are the potential losses. If the stock price falls, you will be required to deposit more money into the margin account to cover the margin call, or the broker may sell some of your shares to cover the losses.

It's important to consider the dividend yield of the stocks you are investing in, as well as the interest rate on the margin loan. If the dividend yield is higher than the interest rate on the margin loan, then the strategy can be profitable in the long run. However, if the dividend yield is lower than the interest rate, then you may not be earning enough passive income to justify the risk of using borrowed money to invest.

Another important factor to consider is the volatility of the stock market. Dividend-yielding stocks can be less volatile than other types of stocks, but there is still a risk of losses if the market as a whole experiences a dow
answers: In addition to the other answers, here's a proper strategy that implements your idea: If the options are priced properly they should account for future dividend payments, so all other things aside, a put option that is currently at the money should be in the money after the dividend, and hence more expensive than a put option that is out of the money today but at the money after the dividend has been paid. The unprotected futures (if priced correctly) should account for dividend payments based on the dividend history and, since maturing after the payment, should earn you (you sell them) less money because you deliver the physical after the dividend has been paid. The protected ones should reflect the expected total return value of the stock at the time of maturity (i.e. the dividend is mentally calculated into the price), and any dividend payments that happen on the way will be debited from your cash (and credited to the counterparty). Now that's the strategy that leaves you with nearly no risk (the only risk you bear is that the dividend isn't as high as you expected).  But for that comfort you have to pay premiums.  So to see if you're smarter than the market, subtract all the costs for the hedging instruments from your envisaged dividend yield and see if your still better than the lending rate.  If so, do the trade.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Are wash sale rules different for stocks and ETFs / Mutual Funds?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, wash sale rules are different for stocks, exchange-traded funds (ETFs), and mutual funds. The wash sale rule is a tax provision that aims to prevent investors from abusing the loss deduction by selling an investment at a loss and then repurchasing the same or substantially identical investment within 30 days.

For stocks, the wash sale rule is triggered when an investor sells a stock at a loss and buys the same or substantially identical stock within 30 days before or after the sale. In this case, the loss is disallowed, and the investor must wait at least 31 days before repurchasing the stock to avoid the wash sale rule.

For ETFs and mutual funds, the wash sale rule works differently. The rule is triggered when an investor sells a fund at a loss and buys a substantially identical fund within 30 days before or after the sale. The loss is disallowed, and the investor must wait at least 31 days before repurchasing the fund to avoid the wash sale rule.

It's important to note that the wash sale rule applies not only to the specific stock, ETF, or mutual fund that was sold at a loss but also to any substantially identical investment. This means that if an investor sells a
answers: The IRS rules are actually the same.  26 U.S. Code § 1091 - Loss from wash sales of stock or securities In   the case of any loss claimed to have been sustained from any sale or   other disposition of shares of stock or securities where it appears   that, within a period beginning 30 days before the date of such sale   or disposition and ending 30 days after such date, the taxpayer has   acquired (by purchase or by an exchange on which the entire amount of   gain or loss was recognized by law), or has entered into a contract or   option so to acquire, substantially identical stock or securities,   then no deduction shall be allowed... What you should take away from the quote above is "substantially identical stock or securities." With stocks, one company may happen to have a high correlation, Exxon and Mobil come to mind, before their merger of course. With funds or ETFs, the story is different. The IRS has yet to issue rules regarding what level of overlap or correlation makes two funds or ETFs "substantially identical."  Last month, I wrote an article, Tax Loss Harvesting, which analyses the impact of taking losses each year. I study the 2000's which showed an average loss of 1% per year, a 9% loss for the decade. Tax loss harvesting made the decade slightly positive, i.e. an annual boost of approx 1%.

Biweekly mortgage payments have gained popularity in recent years as a way for homeowners to pay off their mortgages faster and save money on interest. However, there are some potential catches to consider before adopting this payment schedule.

Firstly, biweekly payments are typically more expensive than making monthly payments. This is because there are more payments per year, which can result in higher total payments over the life of the loan. For example, if you make an extra payment every two weeks, but the interest rate on your loan is high, you may end up paying more in interest over the life of the loan than if you had made fewer, larger payments.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Are capitalization rate and net profit margin the same thing?[/INST]
pred:
No, capitalization rate and net profit margin are not the same thing, although they are related to each other.

Capitalization rate, also known as cap rate, is the ratio of net operating income (NOI) to the property's value. It represents the expected rate of return on investment in a real estate property. Cap rate is calculated by dividing the NOI by the property's value, and it is expressed as a percentage. For example, if a property has an NOI of $100,000 and a value of $1 million, the cap rate would be 10%.

On the other hand, net profit margin is a financial metric that measures the profitability of a business or investment. It represents the percentage of profit earned relative to revenue. Net profit margin is calculated by dividing the net profit by the revenue, and it is expressed as a percentage. For example, if a business has a revenue of $100,000 and a net profit of $20,000, the net profit margin would be 20%.

While both capitalization rate and net profit margin are used to evaluate the financial performance of a real estate investment, they are used for different purposes. Cap rate is used to determine the potential return on investment, while net profit margin is used to evaluate the overall profitability of a business or investment
answers: Both of these terms do refer to your profit; they're just different ways of evaluating it. First, your definition of capitalization rate is flipped.  As explained here, it should be: On the other hand, as explained here: So cap rate is like a reverse unit cost approach to comparing two investments.  If house A costs $1M and you'll make $50K (profit) from it yearly, and house B costs $1.33M and you'll make $65K (profit) from it yearly, then you can compute cap rates to see that A is a more efficient investment from the point of view of income vs. amount-of-money-you-have-stuck-in-this-investment-and-unavailable-for-use-elsewhere. Profit margin, on the other hand, cares more about your ongoing expenses than about your total investment.  If it costs less to maintain property B than it does to maintain property A, then you could have something like: So B is a more efficient investment from the point of view of the fraction of your revenue you actually get to keep each year. Certainly you could think of the property's value as an opportunity cost and factor that into the net profit margin equation to get a more robust estimate of exactly how efficient your investment is.  You can keep piling more factors into the equation until you've accounted for every possible facet of your investment.  This is what accountants and economists spend their days doing. :-)

* Micro lots: 1,000 units of the base currency (EUR or USD)
* Mini lots: 10,000 units of the base currency (EUR or USD)
* Standard lots: 100,000 units of the base currency (EUR or USD)

answers: A lot (sometimes called a round lot) always refers to the quantity of physical good that you're getting, like a carton of eggs or a barrel of oil.  The tricky thing in the case of forex is that the physical good also happens to be a currency. A spot currency product trades in the denomination on the right-hand side (RHS) of the product name.  So if you're buying EUR/USD you are paying USD currency to get EUR "units", and if you're selling EUR/USD you are receiving USD by giving away EUR "units".  The EUR is the "physical good" in this case. The way I remember it is to think of all products (not just currencies) as trading pairs.  So AAPL in my mind is AAPL/USD.  When I buy AAPL/USD I am paying USD to get AAPL units.  When I sell AAPL/USD I am receiving USD by giving away AAPL units. The thing on the left is the physical good (even if it happens to be money) that you are exchanging, and the thing on the right is the money that you are exchanging. So, when I buy a lot of AAPL, I am buying 100 shares at their current price in dollars. Similarly, when I buy a lot of EUR/USD, I am buying 100K Euros at their current price in dollars.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Are RSUs ever taxed as long term capital gains?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, RSUs (Restricted Stock Units) can be taxed as long-term capital gains in certain situations. RSUs are a form of equity compensation that allows employees to receive shares of company stock or the right to receive shares in the future. When an RSU vest, the employee becomes the owner of the underlying stock and receives the shares.

The tax treatment of RSUs depends on whether the RSUs are taxed as ordinary income or as long-term capital gains. Generally, RSUs are taxed as ordinary income when they vest, and the employee recognizes income equal to the fair market value of the underlying stock at the time of vesting. However, if the RSUs are held for more than one year after vesting, they may be eligible for long-term capital gains treatment.

To qualify for long-term capital gains treatment, the RSUs must be held for more than one year after vesting and must not be subject to a substantial risk of forfeiture. If these requirements are met, the RSUs will be taxed at the long-term capital gains rate, which is typically lower than the ordinary income tax rate.

It's important to note that the tax treatment of RSUs can vary depending on individual circumstances, such as the employee's tax bracket, the type of stock received, and any

How does the world - in aggregate - generate a non-zero return? [/INST]

The world, in aggregate, generates a non-zero return through the concept of compounding. Compounding is the process of earning interest on both the initial investment and the accumulated interest over time. When individuals, businesses, and governments invest their money, they earn a return on their investment in the form of interest. This interest is then reinvested, allowing the investment to grow over time.

As more and more money is invested, the aggregate amount of money grows, leading to a non-zero return. This is because the interest earned on the initial investment is added to the principal, allowing the investment to grow at a faster rate over time. For example, if an investor earns a 5% interest rate on their investment, they will earn $5 in interest on a $100 investment. If they then reinvest this $5 in additional investments, they will earn $5.25 in interest on the new investment (5% of $100.25), and so on.

What is a subsidy?[/INST]
pred:
A subsidy is a financial assistance provided by a government or other organization to support a particular industry, business, or activity. The purpose of a subsidy is to offset the costs associated with a particular activity, making it more attractive or affordable for individuals or businesses to participate. Subsidies can take many forms, including direct cash payments, tax credits, or reduced fees.

There are several types of subsidies, including:

1. Direct subsidies: These are direct cash payments made to individuals or businesses to offset the costs of a particular activity. For example, a government may provide direct subsidies to farmers to help them cover the costs of producing a particular crop.
2. Indirect subsidies: These are subsidies that are not provided directly to individuals or businesses, but rather through tax breaks or reduced fees. For example, a government may reduce the taxes paid by a business to help it offset the costs of investing in new equipment.
3. Trade subsidies: These are subsidies provided to support the export of a particular product or service. For example, a government may provide financial assistance to exporters to help them cover the costs of shipping and marketing their products abroad.
4. Research and development subsidies: These are subsidies provided to support research and development (R&D)
answers: A subsidy is a payment made by a group (usually the state) to individuals or corporations in order to shift the balance if the rational economic decision for the individual would be detrimental to the group as a whole otherwise. If the claims that HFCS contribute to obesity are founded, then it is in the public interest to produce less of it, and more alternative foods. Given that a market rather than a planned economy is desired, this cannot be achieved by decree, but rather money is used as an incentive. In a world where all actors make decisions that are fully in their self interest, in principle subsidies would not be needed as consumers would demand healthy rather than cheap foods, and market mechanisms would provide these.

answers: A lien is a mechanism to impede legal title transfer of a vehicle, real property, or sometimes, expensive business equipment.  That's why title companies exist - to make sure there are no liens against something before a buyer hands money to a seller. The lien can be attached to a loan, unpaid labor related to the item (a mechanic's lien) or unpaid taxes, and there are other scenarios where this could occur. The gist of all this is that the seller of the vehicle mentioned does not have clear title if there is a lien.  This introduces a risk for the buyer.  The buyer can pay the seller the money to cover the lien (in the case of a bank loan) but that doesn't mean the seller will actually pay off the loan (so the title is never clear!).  This article recommends visiting the bank with the seller, and getting title on-the-spot.  However, this isn't always an option, as a local bank branch isn't probably going to have the title document available, though the seller might be able to make some arrangement for a local branch to have the title available before a visit to pay off the loan. The low-risk approach is for the seller to have clear title before any money changes hands.

prompt:

What is the meaning of “short selling” or “going short” a stock?[/INST]
pred:
Short selling, also known as "going short" a stock, is a financial strategy in which an investor sells a security they do not own with the expectation of buying it back at a lower price to realize a profit. This strategy is used by investors who believe that the price of a security will decline in value.

In traditional buying and holding, an investor purchases a security with the expectation of earning a profit from its appreciation in value over time. In contrast, short selling involves selling a security that the investor does not own with the expectation of buying it back at a lower price to realize a profit.

To execute a short sale, an investor must borrow the security from a broker or another investor. The investor then sells the borrowed security at the current market price. If the price of the security drops as expected, the investor can buy it back at the lower price and return it to the lender, pocketing the difference as profit.

Short selling can be a profitable strategy in a declining market, but it also carries significant risks. If the price of the security does not drop as expected, the investor may be required to buy it back at a higher price, resulting in a loss. This is known as a "short squeeze," where the price of the security rises rapidly, making it difficult or impossible
answers: The reason for selling a stock "short", is for when you believe the stock value will decrease in the near future. Here is an example: Today Exxon-Mobile stock is selling for $100 / share. You are expecting the price to decrease, so you want to short the stock, which means your broker (i.e. eTrade, etc) allows you to borrow shares without paying money, and those shares are transferred into your account, and then you sell them and receive money for the sale. But you didn't actually own those shares, you only borrowed them, so you need to return the shares to your broker sometime in the future.  Let's say you borrow 10 shares @ $100, and you sell them at the market price of $100, you receive $1,000 in your account. But you owe your broker 10 shares, which you need to return sometime in the future. A few days later, the share price has decreased to $80. Now you can buy 10 shares from the market at a total cost of $800. You get 10 shares, and return those shares to your broker. Since you originally took in $1,000, and you just paid out $800, you keep a resulting profit of $200

Yes, there are several return-on-investment (ROI) vs risk graphs available that can help investors visualize the relationship between potential returns and risk. These graphs are commonly used in financial planning and investment analysis to help investors make informed decisions about their investments.

One of the most well-known ROI vs risk graphs is the risk-return spectrum, which shows the expected return of an investment on the vertical axis and the risk of that investment on the horizontal axis. This graph typically has a curved shape, with higher returns available for higher-risk investments and lower returns for lower-risk investments.

Another useful graph is the Sharpe ratio graph, which shows the expected return of an investment in relation to the risk-free rate and the standard deviation of the investment's returns. The Sharpe ratio is a measure of an investment's excess return relative to the risk it takes on, and the graph can help investors identify investments with high expected returns relative to their risk.

There are also several other ROI vs risk graphs available, including the Sortino ratio graph, the Treynor ratio graph, and the Jensen's alpha graph. These graphs provide different perspectives on the relationship between returns and risk, and can help investors select the most suitable investments for their risk tolerance and investment goals.

answers: As an addition to Chris Rea's excellent answer, these tender offers are sometimes made specifically to cast doubt on the current market price. For instance, a large public company that contracts with a smaller supplier or service company, also public, might make a tender offer below market price. The market will look at this price and the business relationship, and wonder what the larger company knows about the smaller one that they don't. Now, what happens when investors lose confidence in a stock? They sell it, supply goes up, demand goes down, and the price drops. prompt:

Is VAT applied when a tradesman charges for materials?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, VAT (Value-Added Tax) is typically charged on the cost of materials used by a tradesman in their work. VAT is a tax on the value added to goods and services at each stage of production and distribution, and it is typically passed on to the end consumer.

When a tradesman charges for materials, they are considered to be providing a "taxable supply" of those materials. This means that they must account for VAT on the full amount of the materials they charge for, including any VAT that they have paid on the materials themselves.

There are some exceptions to this rule, such as when the tradesman is buying materials for resale or when the materials are used for exempt purposes (such as for charitable purposes). However, these exceptions are limited and do not generally apply to the typical tradesman's use of materials.

It is important for tradesmen to keep accurate records of their materials costs and to account for VAT on these costs in their tax returns. Failure to do so can result in penalties and fines, so it is important to be aware of the VAT implications of using materials in a business.

In summary, VAT is typically charged on the cost of materials used by a tradesman, and it is important for tradesmen to be aware of these VAT implications when charging for materials in their work

answers: Most people will never need to pay federal gift taxes. The federal gift taxes start after giving away 5.34 million over the course of your life. There are only two states that I know of which impose state gift taxes (Connecticut and Minnesota); in Connecticut, you need to start paying taxes if the lifetime value of your gifts exceed two million. If you do make a gift to an individual in excess of 14k, you'll need to file a gift tax return (IRS Form 709). When you file form 709, you won't need to pay taxes until the 5.34 million is exceeded. Instead, you can claim an exemption. Since most people don't exceed that amount, its rare to ever pay taxes even when exceeding the annual exclusion amount. The annual exclusion amount is adjusted each year for inflation.

The Internal Revenue Code (IRC) is clear that taxes must be paid based on the income earned in each tax year, and the government cannot change the tax laws retroactively to tax income that was earned in a previous year.

Under IRC Section 451(a), taxpayers must include in their taxable income for the tax year in which they earn or accrue the income, regardless of when they actually receive the income. This means that if a taxpayer earns income in one fiscal year, they will be taxed on that income in the year it was earned, not in a subsequent year.

There are some exceptions to this rule, such as the "long-term capital gain" exception, which allows taxpayers to delay paying taxes on capital gains until they sell the asset that generated the gain. However, these exceptions are limited and do not apply to most types of income.

It's worth noting that the U.S. government does have the ability to change tax laws retroactively, but this is typically only done in response to changes in the economy or other external factors that affect tax revenues. As a result, the SMI is more sensitive to global cues than it used to be, and its performance is no longer perfectly mirrored by the CHF.

What is the opposite of Economic Bubble? [/INST]
pred:
The opposite of an economic bubble is a stable and sustainable economic environment, where economic growth is driven by fundamentals such as strong demand, innovation, and productivity, rather than by speculative investment and market manipulation. In a stable economy, there is no significant mismatch between asset prices and underlying fundamentals, and the market is not subject to sudden and dramatic changes in sentiment.

An economic bubble, on the other hand, is a situation in which asset prices become detached from their underlying value, driven by speculation and market manipulation rather than by fundamentals. This can occur when investors become overly optimistic about the future prospects of an asset class, leading to a surge in demand and prices that far exceed the underlying value of the assets. As the bubble grows, the prices of assets become increasingly detached from their fundamental value, creating a situation known as a "bubble."

When an economic bubble bursts, the resulting decline in asset prices can be dramatic and can have far-reaching consequences for the economy. In contrast, a stable economy is characterized by steady and sustainable growth, with asset prices reflecting their underlying value and moving in line with economic fundamentals.

Some common indicators of an economic bubble include:

1. Rapid and unsustainable price increases: Asset prices that are rising faster than
answers: The opposite of an economic bubble is a bubble burst :p! Jokes aside though, an economic bubble occurs when the economy is in bull market mode and asset prices are growing very fast. It's usually measured by ratio's like price to earnings and the levels of various market indices. So, the opposite would be when valuations are falling very fast or are very low, and price to earnings ratios are low.  This condition is usually a recession. A recession is a market slowdown, generally after a bubble bursts, and severe recessions can become depressions if they last long enough (Great Depression, 1930s).  A bubble is not necessarily negative - stock prices usually rise a lot so paper wealth is greatly magnified. If you can get out in time, you're golden. Similarly, a recession isn't bad for everyone. Some investors keep large amounts of cash waiting for recessions so they can "buy low, sell high". For most people, however, recessions are negative because unemployment increases and some people get fired, and the economy slows down. Asset prices have fallen so their investments are worth less than they used to be (on paper), and people mainly have to bide it out until the market starts growing again.

5. Check Number: The check number is located in the top right corner of the check, usually in the format of "nnn-nnn-nnn."
6. Payment Amount: The amount of the payment is located in the bottom left corner of the check and is usually in the format of "nnn.nnn."
7. Sign

What does a Dividend “will not be quoted ex” mean?[/INST]
pred:
A dividend "will not be quoted ex" refers to a situation where a company decides not to pay out dividends to its shareholders. This is typically indicated in the company's financial reports or dividend payment schedules.

When a company decides not to pay dividends, it means that it will not distribute any portion of its profits to its shareholders. This can happen for various reasons, such as the company not generating enough profits, or choosing to reinvest its earnings back into the business instead of distributing them to shareholders.

In the context of stock market trading, dividend "will not be quoted ex" means that the company has made a decision not to pay dividends for a particular period of time. This information is typically disclosed in the company's financial reports or press releases, and is important for investors to be aware of when making investment decisions.

It's worth noting that a dividend "will not be quoted ex" does not necessarily mean that the company will never pay dividends again in the future. The company may choose to reinstate its dividend payments at a later time, depending on its financial performance and other factors. However, until the dividend payment is reinstated, the company will not distribute any profits to its shareholders.
answers: One occastion where "will not be quoted ex" is used is when a corporate action is occurring such as a spin-off.  In such a case, the rights to, and the spin-off itself may be quoted separately on the home country exchange.  However, if the company is based abroad, it may not be worth the expense for them to have an additional securities listing on the local (US) exchange. For example:  In November 2016, Yamana Gold (TSX: YRI, NYSE: AUY) announced it will have an initial public offering of a spin-off (Brio Gold, to be listed on TSX as BRIO). These rights were separately traded in advance of the IPO of the spin-off on TSX under "YRI.RT", but the prospectus they stated that the rights "will not be quoted ex" on NYSE, i.e. there was no separate listing on NYSE for these rights. The wording seems counter-intuitive, but I suspect that is the attorneys who were preparing the prospectus used those specific words as they may have a very specific meaning (e.g. from a statute or previous case).

However, it's important to note that this exemption may vary depending on the specific state and local tax laws. Some states may have specific rules or regulations regarding the types of businesses that are eligible for this exemption, or they may have minimum dollar amounts or other requirements that must be met in order to qualify.

answers: In most jurisdictions, both the goods (raw materials) and the service (class) are being "sold" to the customer, who is the end user and thus the sale is subject to sales tax. The teacher should not have to pay sales tax when they buy the flowers from the wholesaler; most jurisdictions charge sales tax on end-user purchases only. However, they are required to have some proof of sales tax exemption for the purchase, which normally comes part and parcel with the DBA or other business entity registration paperwork in most cities/states.  Wholesalers deal with non-end-user sales (exempt from sales tax) all the time, but your average Michael's or Hobby Lobby may not be able to deal with this and may have to charge your friend the sales tax at POS. Depending on the jurisdiction, if this happens, your friend may be able to reduce the amount the customer is paying that is subject to sales tax by the pre-tax value of the materials the customer has paid for, which your friend already paid the tax on.

What is a negotiable security and how are they related to derivatives?[/INST]
pred:
A negotiable security is a financial instrument that can be transferred or sold to another party through a legal process, known as negotiation. These securities are typically issued by corporations, governments, or other organizations, and can be traded on financial markets. Negotiable securities include stocks, bonds, and commercial paper.

Derivatives, on the other hand, are financial contracts that derive their value from an underlying asset or group of assets. Derivatives can be used to hedge risk, speculate on price movements, or gain exposure to an underlying asset without actually owning it. Examples of derivatives include options, futures, and swaps.

There are several ways in which negotiable securities are related to derivatives:

1. Cash settlement: Many derivatives, such as options and futures, are settled in cash rather than physically delivering the underlying asset. The value of these derivatives is determined by the price of the underlying asset, which can be affected by a variety of factors, including changes in interest rates, economic conditions, and company performance.
2. Underlying assets: Negotiable securities can be used as the underlying asset for derivatives. For example, a company may issue a bond that can be used as collateral for a derivatives contract.
3. Hedging: Negotiable securities can be used to hedge
answers: negotiability is a legal concept that permits free transfer of a security without the requirement of prior consent of the issuer.  that means the issuer must pay the current holder of the security, irrespective of who he is.  negotiability also protects a good faith buyer of the instrument from adverse ownership claims of purported prior holders of the instrument.  it is not related to "negotiating" the price or whatnot.  A negotiable security means the current owner does not have to be concerned about acquiring the asset via a bad chain of title b/c he can always assert that he is a "holder in due course" defense against such claims, and have absolute security in his ownership right over the asset.  securities and derivatives are different.  securities are transferrable instruments representing a direct claim on the issuer for the value of the security, whether debt or equity ownership.  derivatives are bilateral contracts, which can only be entered into with the consent of both parties, and can only be transferred by such consent.  derivatives represent a claim against the parties of to the derivative that depends on some economic reference which is outside of the financial condition of the two parties to the contract, such as interest rates, FX rates, commodity prices, etc.

answers: As to where the interest comes from: The same place it comes from in other kinds of savings accounts. No, they don't have to pay you interest -- but if they didn't, you'd be likely to deposit your funds at another bank which did. Their ideal goal is to pay as little as possible without losing depositors, while charging as much as possible without losing borrowers. (yeah, I know, typo corrected) Why do they get higher interest rate than they pay you? Mostly because your deposits and interest are essentially guaranteed, whereas the folks they're lending to may be late paying or default on those loans. In a bankruptcy proceeding, assets are typically valued according to their current value at the time of the bankruptcy filing, rather than their original purchase price or value at the time they were acquired. This is known as the "ongoing value" or "current value" rule.

The reason for this is that the purpose of bankruptcy is to provide a fresh start for the debtor, and to allow them to begin their financial journey anew, free from the burden of excessive debt. If assets were valued at their original purchase price, the debtor would likely be left with little or no assets to use in their new financial life.

For example, let's say an individual purchased a piece of real estate for $100,000 10 years ago. If they file for bankruptcy today, the value of that property may have decreased to $80,000. If the assets were valued according to their original purchase price, the debtor would be left with a significant loss, despite the fact that the property's value has decreased over time. By valuing assets according to their current value, the debtor is able to keep the property and use it as a fresh start, rather than losing it to creditors.

Investing in other currencies, also known as currency hedging, can potentially help mitigate losses in the event of a stock market crash. Here's why:

When you invest in stocks or other assets denominated in a specific currency, any decline in that currency's value against your home currency can lead to a direct loss in the value of your investments. For example, if you invest $10,000 in a U.S. stock portfolio and the U.S. dollar depreciates against your home currency, the value of your investment in U.S. dollars will also decrease. Currency hedging can help protect against these losses by locking in an exchange rate beforehand, ensuring that the value of your investments remains stable regardless of currency fluctuations.

There are several ways to hedge currency risks, including:

1. Forward contracts: These are agreements to exchange a certain amount of one currency for another at a predetermined exchange rate on a future date.
2. Futures contracts: These are standardized agreements to buy or sell a currency at a future date and at a predetermined exchange rate.
3. Options contracts: These give the investor the right, but not the obligation, to exchange a certain amount of one currency for another at a predetermined exchange

While these platforms can provide a convenient way for users to invest and diversify their portfolios, there is a concern that they may be vulnerable to front running, which is a form of insider trading.

In the context of social trading platforms, this could occur when a trader or broker uses information about a particular trade or investment opportunity that is not yet publicly available to front run other users on the platform. This could give the trader or broker an unfair advantage, as they would be able to execute trades before other users have the opportunity to do so.

1. Lack of transparency: Social trading platforms may not provide sufficient transparency around trade execution, making it difficult for users to know when and how trades are being executed.

If a put seller closes early, what happens to the buyer?[/INST]
